# Andrew King (professor)

Andrew King (born 1957) is (since September 2025) Professor Emeritus of English Literature and Literary Studies at the University of Greenwich and, since October 2025, Fellow of the Institute of English Studies, School of Advanced Studies, University of London ( ). From 2019-2022, he was President of the [https://victorianpopularfiction.org/contact/vpfa-board/ Victorian Popular Fiction Association]. He specialises in nineteenth-century periodicals and popular fiction.  He is founding co-editor of [https://victorianpopularfiction.org/publications/1200-2/ Victorian Popular Fictions], the organ of the Victorian Popular Fiction Association.
Early life
Born in Wales from mining and shop-keeping stock, he was encouraged to read classics at University by his school, Porth County Grammar School for Boys. He did a degree in classical and medieval Latin at the University of Reading, followed by an MA in Medieval Studies at the same university. An abortive PhD in Medieval French in Cambridge meant that he went to teach English at the University of Catania, Sicily, where apart from returning to the UK to complete a PGCE and teach for a year in a secondary school, he spent most of the 1980s. In 1990 he married a British council officer and accompanied her on her postings for the 1990s, completing a second MA, this time in English at the University of Sussex, in 1992. In 2000 he completed a PhD in English at Birkbeck College, University of London.
Academic life
In 2003, King obtained his first full-time academic post in the UK. [https://www.canterbury.ac.uk/ Canterbury Christ Church University] appointed him as a senior lecturer in the Media Department. In 2009, after a year's research fellowship at the University of Ghent, he was promoted to Reader in Print History. It was while at Canterbury Christ Church that he published his monograph on The London Journal, and edited two collections of primary sources with John Plunkett from Exeter University:  [https://global.oup.com/academic/product/victorian-print-media-9780199270385?cc=de&lang=en& Victorian Print Media] and [https://www.routledge.com/Popular-Print-Media-1820-1900/King-Plunkett/p/book/9780415322508 Popular Print Media, 1820â€“1900]
Later he guest edited three special numbers of learned journals, including one on [http://www.berghahnjournals.com/view/journals/critical-survey/23/2/critical-survey.23.issue-2.xml Angels and Demons] in Critical Survey, another (with Marysa Demoor of the Ghent University) on the V [http://www.ncgsjournal.com/issue52/issue52.htm ictorian professions, the press and gender] in Nineteenth-Century Gender Studies, while the third was on [http://rs4vp.org/special-issues-of-vpr/ work and leisure]  in Victorian Periodicals Review.
In May 2012 he was appointed Professor of English at the University of Greenwich.
Collections of essays he has since edited with colleagues comprise [https://www.routledge.com/Ouida-and-Victorian-Popular-Culture/author/p/book/9781409405900 Ouida and Victorian Popular Culture] (with Jane Jordan) and, with Alexis Easley and John Morton, the [https://www.routledge.com/The-Routledge-Handbook-to-Nineteenth-Century-British-Periodicals-and-Newspapers/King-Easley-Morton/p/book/9781409468882 Routledge Handbook to Nineteenth-Century Periodicals and Newspapers] and [https://www.routledge.com/Researching-the-Nineteenth-Century-Periodical-Press-Case-Studies/Easley-King-Morton/p/book/9781409468851 Researching the Nineteenth-Century Periodical Press: Case Studies]. Both the latter won the  [http://rs4vp.org/colby-prize Robert and Vineta Colby Prize] for the book published during the preceding year that most advances our understanding of the nineteenth-century British press while [https://www.routledge.com/Work-and-the-Nineteenth-Century-Press-Living-Work-for-Living-People/King/p/book/9781032346557] was short listed for the same prize [https://rs4vp.org/awards/colby-prize/past-winners/].
King has also published a critical edition of [https://www.routledge.com/New-Woman-Fiction-1881-1899-Part-III-vol-7/Oulton-King-March-Russell-Oulton/p/book/9781138755574 The Massarenes], the last full-length novel by Ouida, and written a considerable number of articles, chapters and book reviews as listed on his [http://www.gre.ac.uk/ach/study/llt/staff/andrew-king staff profile page].
His latest research in periodicals derives from his discovery of the dearth of research on trade periodicals as mediated communications. This crystallised in 2016 into [https://www.blt19.co.uk/ BLT19], a digitisation project centred on Victorian periodicals concerned with various aspects of work, and into the first real overview of Victorian trade and professional periodicals for [https://edinburghuniversitypress.com/book-the-edinburgh-history-of-the-british-and-irish-press-volume-2.html   The Edinburgh History of the British and Irish Press, Volume 2, 2020, edited by David Finkelstein].
In 2019, he co-founded [https://victorianpopularfiction.org/publications/1200-2/ Victorian Popular Fictions], the organ of the [https://victorianpopularfiction.org/contact/vpfa-board/ Victorian Popular Fiction Association], of which he became Acting and then Elected President 2018-2022.
